The SE Cathedral in Goa is an architectural marvel steeped in history and grandeur.
I was awestruck by the intricate details of its Portuguese-Gothic design, from the imposing facades to the ornate altars.

Showcasing the region's captivating art and culture.
This grand structure is dedicated to St. Catherine of Alexandria.
Its construction began in 1562 under the reign of King Dom Sebastião of Portugal and was completed in 1619, with the cathedral being consecrated in 1640.
The architectural style is predominantly Portuguese-Manueline, featuring a Tuscan exterior and a Corinthian interior.
The church is built in the form of a Greek cross inside, though it appears rectangular from the outside.
The cathedral originally had two towers, but the southern tower collapsed in 1776 and was never rebuilt, adding a touch of historical intrigue to the site.
Inside, visitors can marvel at the main altar dedicated to St. Catherine, flanked by stunning old paintings and several intricately carved chapels.
Chapel of the Cross of Miracles with intricately carved chapels, where a vision of Christ is said to have appeared in 1919.

The cathedral's bell, known as the "Golden Bell," is a notable highlight.

Located in Old Goa, is one of the largest and most magnificent churches in Asia.

The cathedral commemorates the Portuguese victory over a Muslim army led by Afonso de Albuquerque on the feast day of St. Catherine, which led to the dedication of the cathedral in her honor.
Not just a place of worship but a historical treasure trove that offers a glimpse into Goa’s colonial past and architectural grandeur.
